abstract.p: New York Knickerbockers continue pursuit of forward Brian Grant, who reportedly plans to meet with team officials in New York (M)

block.p: While the two biggest targets of the free-agent pool may have eluded them, the Knicks are continuing their pursuit of Portland's hard-nosed power forward, Brian Grant.
According to a person familiar with Grant's plans, the 28-year-old forward will fly to New York this week to visit with the Knicks, something that they could not coax Grant Hill or Tim Duncan to do.
While the two biggest targets of the free-agent pool may have eluded them, the Knicks are continuing their pursuit of Portland's hard-nosed power forward, Brian Grant.
According to a person familiar with Grant's plans, the 28-year-old forward will fly to New York this week to visit with the Knicks, something that they could not coax Grant Hill or Tim Duncan to do.

Because of the Knicks' salary-cap situation, it is believed that it will take a sign-and-trade agreement to bring Grant to New York and the Trail Blazers' asking price is likely to be either Latrell Sprewell or Allan Houston.

Grant opted out of his contract this summer, escaping a deal that would have paid him an additional $40 million over the next four seasons, and if he were to leave Portland, it would be for playing time, not money. He averaged a career-low 21 minutes per game this season, averaging just 7.3 points and 5.5 rebounds per game.

The Knicks are still awaiting the arrival of Frederic Weiss, the 1999 No. 1 draft pick. He remained in France to be with his father, who was ill, and has still not made the trip. Camp begins tomorrow.
''It would have been nice to have him in much sooner, so we could get a look at him,'' General Manager Scott Layden said.
